bib_record.title: Fragment angular momenta in low and medium energy fission of 242-Pu

free_txt: Variable energy cyclotron at
Calcutta (VECC)
From the photopeak areas of the gamma rays of
The nuclides' independent isomeric yields were
determined using usual decay-growth equations after
for correcting the precursor contribution.
fragment angular momenta estimated from the measured
isomer ratios using the statistical model analysis
showed significantly larger fragment angular momenta
in the medium energy fissioning system compared to
the low energy fissioning system. This has been
attributed to the effect of higher excitation energy
and angular momentum in the entrance channel leading
to increased fragment temperature, moments of inertia
and angular velocity.
The resultant precipitate of silver antiomonide,
dissolved in dil. HNO3, was counted on a 45 cc HPGe
detector coupled to a 4 K MCA in live time. The
resolution of the detector was 2.2 keV at 1332 keV.
The  gamma spectra indicated that there was no
contamination from other fission products in the
separated antimony isotopes.
The error on an individual measurement is
about 15 % which is the compounded error due to
counting statistics, the uncertainties on the
gamma-ray abundances, the fractional cumulative yield
(FCY) 128-Sn, the irradiation and separation  times
and the half lives. The errors quoted on the mean
isomeric yield ratios are the precision of the
measurements.
Variable energy cyclotron at
Calcutta (VECC)
After the irradiation, the front
side catcher of the irradiated target was dissolved
with NaOH in presence of antimony carrier. Antimony
was separated from the active solution by distilling
antimony hydride and collecting into silver nitrate
solution. The resultant precipitate of silver
antiomonide, dissolved in dil. HNO3, was counted on
a 45 cc HPGe detector coupled to a 4 K MCA in live
time mode.
fission fragment angular momenta (Jrms)
Uranium foils of thickness 71 mg/cm**2 covered with
6.75 mg/cm**2 thick superpure aluminium foils were
Irradiated with 40.0 p/m 0.4 MeV alpha particle beam
at VECC, Calcutta with beam current of 1.0-2.0 micro
ampere.
By Dr.B.S.Tomar, RCD, BARC
